intro: Machadoa huillensis, commonly known as the Huillén machadoa, is a perennial flowering plant native to the Andes Mountains of South America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes parsley and carrots, and is characterized by its umbel-like inflorescence. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, showcasing adaptations to high-altitude conditions. Its foliage consists of finely divided, aromatic leaves, and it produces small, white or pale yellow flowers. Machadoa huillensis is of interest to botanists due to its unique ecological niche and potential medicinal properties.
